title: Essential IELTS Grammar Guide
description: Comprehensive grammar reference for IELTS Writing and Speaking

sections.title: Complex Sentence Structures
sections.explanation: Complex sentences demonstrate grammatical range and help you express sophisticated ideas. They combine independent and dependent clauses using subordinating conjunctions.

rules.rule: Use subordinating conjunctions to create complexity

examples.correct: Although technology has improved communication, it has also increased social isolation.
examples.explanation: 'Although' introduces a dependent clause, creating a complex sentence that shows contrast.

examples.correct: Since renewable energy costs have fallen dramatically, many countries are transitioning away from fossil fuels.
examples.explanation: 'Since' shows cause-effect relationship in a complex structure.

commonMistakes.incorrect: Although technology has improved communication. It has also increased social isolation.
commonMistakes.correct: Although technology has improved communication, it has also increased social isolation.
commonMistakes.explanation: Don't create a sentence fragment by putting a period after the dependent clause.

examples.correct: While some argue that education should be free, others believe that charging fees ensures quality, which is why this debate continues.
examples.explanation: This sentence combines three clauses with different relationships (contrast, reason, result).

practice.instruction: Combine these simple sentences into one complex sentence:
practice.simple: 1. Technology improves efficiency. 2. It creates job displacement. 3. This causes social problems.
practice.answer: Although technology improves efficiency, it creates job displacement, which causes social problems.
alternatives: While technology improves efficiency, the job displacement it creates causes social problems.
Technology improves efficiency; however, the resulting job displacement causes social problems.

sections.title: Conditional Sentences
sections.explanation: Conditionals express hypothetical situations and their consequences. IELTS essays often require discussing potential outcomes.

examples: If you heat water to 100Â°C, it boils.
If people exercise regularly, they generally feel healthier.

types.structure: If + present simple, will + base verb
types.use: Express real possibilities in the future
examples: If governments invest in renewable energy, they will reduce carbon emissions.
If the current trend continues, urban populations will exceed rural populations by 2050.

types.structure: If + past simple, would + base verb
examples: If governments banned single-use plastics, pollution would decrease significantly.
If education were completely free, more people would pursue higher qualifications.

types.structure: If + past perfect, would have + past participle
types.use: Express hypothetical past situations and their consequences
examples: If countries had acted sooner on climate change, current temperatures would not have risen so dramatically.
If the internet had not been invented, modern communication would have developed very differently.

types.use: Express complex hypothetical relationships across time periods
examples: If the government had invested in infrastructure earlier, traffic congestion would not be such a problem now.
If people were more environmentally conscious, we would not have caused so much damage in the past.

commonMistakes.incorrect: If governments will invest in education, society will benefit.
commonMistakes.correct: If governments invest in education, society will benefit.
commonMistakes.explanation: Don't use 'will' in the if-clause of first conditionals.

commonMistakes.incorrect: If I would be rich, I would travel the world.
commonMistakes.correct: If I were rich, I would travel the world.
commonMistakes.explanation: Use past simple (or 'were' for 'to be') in second conditional if-clauses, not 'would.'

sections.title: Passive Voice
sections.explanation: Passive voice emphasizes actions over actors, creating a more formal, objective tone appropriate for academic writing.

structures.passive: New policies were implemented (by the government).

structures.active: Researchers have discovered a new method.
structures.passive: A new method has been discovered (by researchers).

structures.active: We should address climate change immediately.
structures.passive: Climate change should be addressed immediately.

when: When the actor is unknown or unimportant: 'The building was constructed in 1995.'
To maintain focus on the topic: 'Environmental damage has been caused by industrial pollution.'
For formal, objective tone: 'It is believed that education improves social mobility.'
To avoid repetition: 'The study examined 500 participants. They were divided into three groups.'

sentences: It is widely accepted that climate change poses a significant threat.
Several solutions have been proposed to address urban congestion.
The research was conducted over a five-year period.

sections.title: Relative Clauses
sections.importance: Essential for adding detail and sophistication
sections.explanation: Relative clauses add information about nouns, allowing you to pack more meaning into sentences without creating choppy writing.

examples: Students who study regularly achieve better results. (Which students? Those who study regularly)
Countries that invest in education see economic benefits. (Which countries? Those that invest)
The policy which was implemented last year has reduced pollution.
Denmark, which has invested heavily in renewable energy, generates most electricity from wind.
My professor, who has researched this topic for 20 years, believes significant change is possible.
The Internet, which was developed in the 1960s, has transformed communication.

pronouns.example: The scientist who discovered this lives in Germany. / The scientist whom I mentioned won a Nobel Prize.
The car which I bought is very fuel-efficient.
The book that I read explained this concept well.
Scientists whose research focuses on climate change often work internationally.
Cities where public transport is excellent have less traffic congestion.

commonMistakes.incorrect: My friend, that lives in London, is visiting.
commonMistakes.correct: My friend, who lives in London, is visiting.
commonMistakes.explanation: Use 'who,' not 'that,' in non-defining relative clauses.

commonMistakes.incorrect: Denmark which has invested in renewable energy, generates clean electricity.
commonMistakes.correct: Denmark, which has invested in renewable energy, generates clean electricity.
commonMistakes.explanation: Non-defining relative clauses require commas on both sides.

sections.title: Articles (a/an/the)
sections.explanation: Articles are small but critical. Errors with articles are noticeable and can lower your grammar score.

uses: General examples: 'A healthy diet includes vegetables.'
examples: A smartphone has become essential for modern communication.
An effective solution requires cooperation.

uses: Second mention: 'A study was conducted. The study found...'
Unique things: 'the sun, the internet, the government'
Specific things both speaker and listener know: 'the solution to this problem'
examples: The internet has transformed communication.
The government should invest in education.
The solution to climate change requires global cooperation.

uses: Plural/uncountable nouns (general): 'Education is important. / Children need nutrition.'
examples: Technology has changed society.
Education improves social mobility.
Children require proper nutrition.

commonMistakes.incorrect: The education is important for society.
commonMistakes.explanation: Use no article with uncountable nouns used generally.

commonMistakes.correct: The government should invest in infrastructure.
commonMistakes.explanation: Use 'the' with government when referring to a specific country's government.

bandDescriptors.band9: Uses a wide range of structures with full flexibility and accuracy; rare minor errors occur only as 'slips'
bandDescriptors.band8: Uses a wide range of structures; majority of sentences are error-free; makes only very occasional errors
bandDescriptors.band7: Uses a variety of complex structures; produces frequent error-free sentences; has good control of grammar and punctuation but may make a few errors
bandDescriptors.band6: Uses a mix of simple and complex sentence forms; makes some errors in grammar and punctuation but they rarely reduce communication
bandDescriptors.band5: Uses only a limited range of structures; attempts complex sentences but these tend to be less accurate than simple sentences

practiceExercises.instruction: Identify and correct the grammatical errors in these sentences:

sentences.incorrect: If governments will invest more in education, society will benefit greatly.
sentences.correct: If governments invest more in education, society will benefit greatly.
sentences.error: Incorrect use of 'will' in first conditional if-clause

sentences.incorrect: Technology who has transformed communication continues to evolve rapidly.
sentences.correct: Technology which has transformed communication continues to evolve rapidly.

sentences.incorrect: The education is essential for economic development.
sentences.correct: Education is essential for economic development.
sentences.error: No article needed with uncountable nouns used generally

practiceExercises.instruction: Combine these simple sentences into one complex sentence using appropriate grammatical structures:

exercises.answer: As renewable energy becomes cheaper, many countries are adopting it, which reduces carbon emissions.
